Megalofonos, N.G. Papayannakos * Laboratory of Chemical Process Engineering, Department of Chemical Engineering, National Technical University of Athens, Heroon Polytechiou 9, GR-157 73 Zografos, Athens, Greece Received 21 April 1995; revised 16 September 1995; accepted 16 September 1995 Abstract The reaction of methane and hydrogen sulphide over a Pt-A1203 catalyst has been studied in a fixed bed tubular reactor over a temperature range of 973 to 1073 K under atmospheric pressure and for space times between 0.1 and 1 s. The Langmuir-Hinshelwood-Hougen-Watson theory has been employed to obtain eighteen (18) rival kinetic models. The kinetic parameters are determined for all models and discrimination of the prevailing model is attempted by using statistical and thermodynamic constraints. According to that model the rate-controlling step is the reaction between one chemisorbed CH2 and two S on the catalytic surface with the participation of three catalytic sites. Keywords: Alumina-platinum; Hydrogen sulphide; Methane; Kinetics 1. Introduction Hydrogen is valuable both as a chemical feedstock and as a clean energy source. As environmental demands for cleaner fuels are steadily increasing, the role of hydrogen both as a feedstock in the petroleum industry for upgraded fuel and as a 'green' energy source is expected to rise as well. Among the most hydrogen-consuming processes in the petroleum refineries today is the hydro- treatment of petroleum fractions, mainly to remove heteroatoms, such as sulphur and nitrogen, decrease aromaticity as well as improve cuts characteristics. The hydrogen sulphide produced is further directed to Claus process units where sulphur is produced and hydrogen is converted to water [1-5]. * Corresponding author Tel. (+ 30-1) 7723239, fax. (+30-1) 7723155, npap@offeas.chemeng.ntua.gr. 0926-860X/96/$15.00 1996 Elsevier Science B.V. All rights reserved SSDI 0926-860X(95)00227-8 e-mail 40 S.K. Megalofonos, N.G. Papayannakos / Applied Catalysis A: General 138 (1996) 39-55 Steam-reforming has been for a long time the principal method for the production of hydrogen. According to this method, hydrogen is generated by the reaction of steam with natural gas or desulphurised light hydrocarbons at temperatures of 650-950 while carbon oxides are produced as by-products [4,51. As scientists have been striving to achieve larger yields of hydrogen, their experimental efforts are focusing on alternative methods and processes for hydrogen production. A proposed method for hydrogen production is the decomposition of hydrogen sulphide [1-3]. However, as the decomposition of hydrogen sulphide is not thermodynamically favourable [2,6] the direct reaction between methane and hydrogen sulphide is suggested as an alternative process for hydrogen production [6,7]. This alternative approach was considered in view of the two-fold use. The first is that the strong pollutant hydrogen sulphide is used for the production mainly of hydrogen, a clean energy source and a valuable chemical as long as the solvent carbon disulphide is produced as a by product. The second is that the gas mixture produced can further react under different conditions to produce light hydrocarbons [8]. The use of platinum catalysts in catalytic reforming is well known from previous studies [9]. Platinum catalysts have also the ability to catalyze hydro- genation and dehydrogenation reactions. Besides, these catalysts catalyze the decomposition of hydrogen sulphide [ 1,9]. Object of this paper is the study of the kinetics of the methane-hydrogen sulphide catalytic reaction by using Pt-AI203 as a catalyst, in the temperature range of 973-1073 K and at 0.1 MPa pressure. 2. Experimental Two coaxial a-Al203 tubes in a downflow configuration were used as reactor. The internal diameter of the outer tube was 11.5 mm and the external diameter of the inner tube was 5.5 mm. The tube length was 0.80 m. A four zone electric furnace was regulating the temperature distribution in the reactor in accordance with the experimental requirements, using four electronic con- trollers. The temperature was monitored by thermocouples placed at fixed points outside the outer tube as well as inside the inner tube. One inner travelling thermocouple was also used to measure the temperature distribution along the reactor length in the course of each experiment. The accuracy of the temperature measurements was _ 1 K. The reactor feed gas was a mixture of H2S and CH4. The H2S and CH4 flow rates at the inlet of the reactor were measured independently using a capillary system calibrated with a bubble flowmeter. The total volumetric flow rate was measured at the reactor outlet using a bubble S.K. Megalofonos, N.G. The gas composition at the inlet of the reactor was double checked through the measurement of the inlet flow rates and by gas chromatography. A maximum deviation of 2% was observed. The input-output mass balances were checked in each experiment and their differences were found to be less than 3%. The gas composition at the reactor inlet and outlet was determined by a gas chromatograph bearing a thermal conductivity detector and a 5.48 m Porapak-Q column. Nitrogen was used as carrier gas. The gas chromatograph was cali- brated with pure H2S, CH4 and H2 gases and with gas mixtures of CH4 and CS2. All gases employed in the experiments were of a purity over 99.5% with the exception of the carrier gas for the gas chromatograph, the purity of which was 99.999%. The catalyst used was a Pt-A1203 (KCE Platinum catalyst E 603) with 0.43% wt Pt. Its density was 1.41 g/cm3 with a void fraction of 0.65, specific surface area 104 m2/g and mean pore radius 6.9 nm. The experiments have been performed in two catalytic beds of different mass and particles size, for the experimental test of the impact of the intraparticle transfer phenomena upon the study of the kinetics of the methane-hydrogen sulphide reaction. Characteristics of these two beds are given in Table 1. 3. Results and discussion 3.1. Proposed kinetic models and reaction paths In the kinetic study of the methane-hydrogen sulphide reaction, it is assumed that two chemical reactions take place: The hydrogen sulphide-methane reac- tion to carbon disulphide and hydrogen and the catalytic decomposition of hydrogen sulphide to sulphur and hydrogen. Although not favoured thermody- namically, the latter is a very rapid one [3,6]. Methane dimerization reactions are of no interest for the purposes of the present study as they are slow [10-12] and not favoured thermodynamically [6], and thus not taken into account along with the rest of the reactions taking place in the gas phase. 42 S.K. The homogeneous thermal reactions The homogeneous hydrogen sulphide-methane thermal reaction was found to be of negligible importance compared to the catalytic one. The conversions to carbon disulphide obtained with the empty reactor were within the experimental error of the measured values for the whole range of experimental conditions. 3.3. Conclusions Eighteen kinetic models for the catalytic reaction of methane and hydrogen sulphide over a Pt-A1203 catalyst have been studied. The proposed kinetic model indicates that the rate-controlling step is the reaction between one chemisorbed CH2 and two chemisorbed S species with the participation of three catalytic sites. The activation energy of this step was calculated as 103 100 cal/mol. The only products yielded are hydrogen, carbon disulphide and small amounts of sulphur. The kinetics of H2S decomposition over the Pt-A1203 catalyst is also presented. 5.
